reviews.review_text: I must say I ended up being somewhat disappointed. In case you never heard of this, it's a turn based roleplaying game set in a post apocalyptic world, extremely similiar to Fallout (the original Wasteland 1 is the spirtiual predecessor to Fallout). It offers a very good amount of content and great athmosphere. The world is well built and interesting. The story is ok (you pretty much just help local folks, the big bad only rears its ugly head every few hours for a line or two) - it's a game that is living more off the lore than off the plot, which is totally fine (see for an excellent example: Morrowind). The disappointing part is everything else. The attribute and skill system is just bad. There are only 3 viable character builds attribute wise. Attributes are completely detached from skills, so the only thing attributes concern is combat. So there are strong guys who can walk fast (melee) and guys who can shoot well and often (sniper) and intelligence chars who suck at combat but get more skills (skill donkey).   There are a ton of skills, for example lockpicking, animal whispering or mechanical repair, as you'd expect from a RPG. But the difficulty scaling of skill checks is made in such a way that you need expert characters to keep up with the skill checks. So every character just gets 2 skills you'll dump all your skill points in every few levels. There is no customization or thinking involved in building a character after it is created and you start the game. Every level is just new skill points you have to spend in the same skills every time. Terribly boring. The skill checks themselves also ultimately become boring as hell, because every single chest in the game is locked AND trapped. It just becomes an annoying chore to disarm and open it. The reward is usually just 3 bullets of ammo and a bit of junk to vendor off. You'll also constantly come across containers with only 10-30% success chance. Prepare for the exciting meta gameplay of quicksaving and then trying and reloading as long as it takes to finally open the junk. Or simply ignoring it. But at least early on, the game is balanced around you really going after every scrap. Later on it becomes irrelevant instead.  And the biggest problem, the combat system is very very bad. It looks like another take on the tried and true Jagged Alliance/XCOM formular. Only it's the blandest iteration I've seen so far. There are no skills, no classes. There is just one type of cover. At the end of the day there is nothing to do but just sit down all your chars behind a wall and keep firing at the nearest enemy until the fight is over. By the end I didn't even bother with cover anymore. I just left my guys standing in a big blob where the combat started and kept shooting. That's how dumb the combat here is. The maps also only very rarely offer interesting tactical opportunities. Most maps seem to have been made with aesthetics in mind and not tactics. Blackguards for example was WAY more inventive here, where you could clearly tell that the designers hand crafted every encounter and tried to get a unique twist out of every battle. In Wasteland it's just cannon fodder fights with a random fence you can use as cover if you want, or not, it won't make much of a difference.  Don't get me wrong, it's not a terrible game. What kept me going was exploring the world and seeing how the small surviving communities in this world worked. Still, I can't help but feel terribly disappointed over the massively wasted potential on display here.

Wasteland 2 is a decent CRPG, but it's lacking in the depth that FO1 and 2 offered.  The character creation is intimidating at first, but the manual will explain things. For the most part it avoids having any single attribute as a dump stat, although charisma and luck come close. The skill system could use some work. Three dialogue skills is two too many, and a lot of non-combat skills are just various ways to open loot crates, although there are several cases where high repair or demolitions are needed to progress in a quest. Strangely, your attributes only affect your derived stats - the majority of which are sadly hidden from you - but have no effect on your skills.  Combat is a huge part of this game, and while it is fun it's also rather simple. It uses a turn based system similar to Fallout, but you get control of each member of your party. There's an ambush attack similar to overwatch from XCOM which is pretty useful, but there aren't any aimed shots except for headshots, which are pretty boring. The weapons are seriously imbalanced, with assault rifles becoming really good about 1/3 of the way through, and godlike in the end-game.  The quest design is decent; there are a handful of major quests in both areas of the game that are pretty complex and fulfilling to solve but the majority of them are short and combat focused. The quests in the first half are more polished while the back half feels rushed and incomplete.  Wasteland 2 is worth playing especially if you loved the old Fallout games and wish Van Buren was real. A word of warning: the game can still have some pretty poor performance even if you meet recommended specs.

I had been looking forward to this game's release for a long time. A lot of things were done quite well. I liked the general setting and story outline and the fact it used turn based combat, but there are a huge number of letdowns in this game.     Plot. I think it's supposed to feel immersive, but I just didn't feel like it was. Other than radio messages and a couple of places overrun by end-boss henchmen, nothing connects the end of the game to the start or middle. There is no feeling of building to an epic conclusion. The side-quests are fine.     Skills. There is hardly any synergy between stats.Your Computer Science skill character for example, his intelligence level is irrelevant on skill checks... that makes no sense. I think it would have been much better to keep skills more closely linked with stats. Partly I think this has happened because of the ludicrous number of skills/stats. There is just no point in having safecracking, lock-picking and alarm disabling as separate skills. Less skills, less stats, less skill points and this problem would have gone away. Also, especially the stats feel very ineffectual, each char might get 2 or 3 points to allocate throughout the game. What can you get for them? Not a lot.     Skill-checks. I'm guessing there are 2 kinds of players, ones who try and fail to open lockboxes/doors/safes and accept that and move on (potentially to lobbing grenades at it) or ones who will save/reload until it opens. The system in place does not really handle it that well for either. The randomness is just a complete waste of time. If the former type of player got to a box and the tooltip says the skillcheck is too low, that would be fine, they could move on. If the latter type of player did the same, ditto. It's just making busy work for people who want to explore event inch of the game and open all the chests. Later in the game there are chests that will be 20% chance to open with maximum Lockpicking + Luck... what is the point in that? If it's supposed to be because sometimes in lfe you can't overcome a challenge... then just make it that you find lockboxes which can't be opened at all.     Using skills. There is no reason for it to take several seconds to try and fail/succeed to perform some action, especially if you have to do it several times in succession. Mine fields are a prime example... Quicksave, right-click, disarm, wait, wait, wait, repeat. How tedious. Combine near instant usage with some absolute (i.e. not random) skill-check like I describe in (3) and it would have made the game a lot less annoying.     Combat - Tactics. This is perhaps the biggest letdown. There is no excuse for this at all, the combat is incredibly dull and you inevitably start to feel like your trying to trick the game's AI instead of trying to waste some raiders.     Combat - Positioning. This could have had a big effect on most battles, making them more tactical and thus more interesting, but in the majority of cases (especially in the end-game battles) the bad guys are entrenched and you come in the door and the battle (or cut scene leading to battle) begins. It would have been a lot better if there was some kind of stealth skills that you could have used to get into better positions. Also, it would have been great if there was a way to tell whether you were in an NPCs line of sight so trying to position your squad cleverly wasn't an annoying save-reload procedure.     Combat - Cover. I like cover, it's a fun mechanic, however, because of the positioning, often by the time you reach it you could have already won. The last few battles I felt were pretty crap tactically because it was almost impossible to make decent use of cover. Also, if you have any melee characters, obviously they can't really make use of cover so should be appropriately armoured...     Combat - Melee/Brawl. ... which they aren't. My blunt weapons dude was maxxed out on strength with all the armor and constitution and crit dmg reduction perks... he was still a ridiculously easy target. In the end game, if he got into melee range before being killed that was a surprise. Massively disappointing. Made worse by...     Combat - Armor. ... the fact that heavy armor makes you slower. Ok, that makes some sense, however it makes melee chars slow (especially as they'd have to have taken high strength to be useful at the cost of other stats, like speed) and thus less able to get into position to pummel the enemy. I get that having the whole squad in (enclave) power armor (FO2 stylee!!) doesn't make a lot of sense, but combat speed was the stupidest thing to reduce when wearing it. Much better would have been a loss of coordination or evasion. You can make it RP by saying that it's like mech armor, giving them more speed to make up for the heavy armor. In the end-game, melee is almost completely useless as there are snipers who can take them out in a couple of shots. Conductive armor... this is a stupid idea, if you are struck by lightning/energy weapons, the best thing you could be wearing was a huge suit of power armor as the faraday cage effect would ensure the wearer remain unscathed, it's basic physics. This all basically means you have to carry 2 sets of armor around per person to ensure you can change when a battle will be energy weapon heavy. This is a massive hassle and adds very little to the game. I think it would have been better if the novel use of energy weapons was that they were less applicable to precision strikes (for obvious reasons), but overall a little more powerful than regular weapons to compensate. Make them a little better against robots and a little less against biological targets, by all means. Having your energy weapons guy be almost entirely useless for the first half of the game... great!     Combat - Followers. Maybe these guys aren't meant to last long in combat? When they 'bum-rush' the enemy in every fight you either do a lot of save/reloading to keep them alive, or just let them die and get on with it. Kind of a pity.     Combat - Healing. Given that in any tough fight, unless your party is 100% snipers and assault rifles, people will have to move in closer, and will get incapacitated... Having the surgeon get to them is nearly always impossible in combat as it takes more than 1 round to get them back on their feet, in which time the surgeon will almost certainly be out in the open and gunned down. Also, you use surgeon to get people back on their feet after a fight, great... but now they have a real-time (some are 600 seconds!!), unremovable debuff reducing their stats. What is that for? Mandatory bathroom breaks? All it does is introduce an annoying time delay before you can go into combat again.      Weapon types - Nobody wanted to use weapons other than sniper/assault rifles right? Oh, you did? Well, that's too bad because they are pretty crap.     Car - One of the best ideas in Fallout 2. It allowed you to move around the map a lot faster (not a huge Wasteland 2 problem), but more importantly, you had your 'bank' nearby, so when you get to a place you can go and grab that heavy quest item or 'white' item when you find someone who wants it without having to go all the way back to base, then inside the base to the chest, then all the way back again. Definitely should have existed here.   In summary. The game wasn't terrible, but particularly the combat was a big let down. While there are some new things from where Fallout 2 was (oh Marcus... did you just kill 2 of your own party members with your minigun...again!?), this game did not get them right. Given that we're 17 years down the road in terms of game design, it should have been much, much better.

Pros: + Sequel for the original Wasteland + High difficulty level + Looks and sounds decent + Great nostalgia feeling of how great the games used to be + No DLC or microtransactions crap  Cons: - Might not open to 21 century players, who are used to 'easy' games - Minor design flaws (no 'Resting' option for example)  Do I recommend? If you ever played the original Wasteland and Fallout series and liked them, then I definitely recommend this game to you.  Verdict: 8.5 / 10 - Really good game (1 = do-not-bother game 5 = average game 10 = must own game)

This is NOT AT ALL like Fallout 1 and 2 or similar classic CRPGs which offer significant choices and freedom, interesting dialogue, chances to use your creativity.  It's mechanical in the most boring way. You march linearly through a sequence of mostly empty areas. In each area, you do the same tedious and repetitive click-and-wait, which is all minor variations on the following minigame: find box, disarm trap [wait], disarm alarm [wait], unlock lock [wait], unlock tumbler [wait]. The waiting really is excessive. If you accidentally click things in the wrong order, which is guaranteed to happen since the click-wait dance is so boring, the box blows up or the alarm goes off. When you succeed, you get some minor loot. Which you must hold on to forever, because there is only one container in the entire game that you can put things in, and the game tells you things are junk when they might be useful.  Skills are all for boring skill checks like this; too few points, and you'll keep failing and waiting over and over, or have to take the long route through the area. That's too bad, since skills are your only way of interacting with the world outside combat.  Occasionally an area contains a friendly NPC. I guarantee that NPC has nothing interesting to say, and don't expect deep dialogue trees with important and rewarding decisions. Even the writing is boring. Just click all the topics until they go away to update quest status. Then go to some other area, do same tedious boxes-and-combat dance, come back to turn in quest for reward. Your reward is to level up and increase the mandatory weapon and box-opening skills. These are also illusory choices, because if you put points into the wrong skills, you will just be waiting more. It turns out there's one optimal way to make a character, this is impossible to determine before you have played the game or copied the perfect recipe, and if you didn't do it, the game is even more tedious. Unlike Fallout, you can't make weird characters like a a low-intelligence talker character or a nonviolent sleazeball work out. Just restart and build the character in the combat-oriented way you are forced to do.  What this leaves is a ton of unavoidable turn-based combat - which is decent, though simplistic; it mainly tests whether you put enough points into the right gun skills, because several of the gun skills are really not worthwhile.   Please do not buy this game unless turn-based combat is your primary interest. It's a 'tactics' game. If you expect anything else, you'll be disappointed. If what you want is an RPG with choices, run away. There are no real choices. Your choices (such as they are) are morally 1-dimensional, you can't affect the politics or world in any interesting way, and it's not really possible to be bad or even strange. The only thing it is possible to be is a character which marches through the predetermined missions shooting things as intended.

Scratches an itch that I've had since 1999. Feels good man.   Pros + Fully customizable squad of 4 Rangers. You assign their starting stats and skills, pick their starting wardrobe, and can even give them their own backstory. + Fantastic turn based combat that takes advantage of cover and line of sight. + Well written quest lines and dialogue. + An atmosphere that mixes the brutality of the wasteland with minor camp, but doesn't overdo either. +No stealth!  Cons -The View Map screen is quite poor. Very small. No landmarkers. No ability to add your own landmarks. No ability to move your squad to a place on the map by clicking on a location via the map screen. -Some maps are a large jumbled messes. It's hard to understand where you are and where you are going, even with a UI compass. -There are some dead stat points that provide no bonuses, forcing you into a break point if you want x bonus from your stats. -No stealth!

I have played both Wasteland 2 and Wasteland 2: Director's Cut. I *really* wanted to like this game, and there are things I do like about this game, but unfortunately they are overshadowed by several design decisiosn that I feel are completely game breaking, decisions that ultimately left me feeling nothing but disappointment.  To get this out of the way first, yes, there were a *lot* of bugs, from graphics not lining up properly, to strange problems with the names of clothing, to crashes to desktop on load, to a horrific problem in Ranger Citadel where attempts to load the game in Ranger Citadel would leave me with a completely crippled interface and the feeling that I had somehow broken the game so much that it would never recover. To be clear, while these were annoyances (yes, even the Ranger Citadel bug for which I eventually found a work-around), none of them were bad enough to actually make me dislike the game.  Also, to get THIS out of the way, I agree that the visual style could have used some work, and the audio definitely left something to be desired, especially the background noises which, in the Ag Center, nearly had me tearing my hair out at one point. But, again, none of this actually made me dislike the game.  Instead, up to a point I liked the game *in spite* of these problems. I liked the combat system. Sure it was relatively light on tactics if I wanted to just plough through encounters, but if I was smart, I could end encounters in one or two rounds. I liked the weapon and armor system well enough. They were definitely servicable, and modding weapons was kind of fun. I liked character customization well enough. The perks and quirks were a nice addition. I also liked some of the rebalancing, and felt like my characters in the DC were better able to handle themselves in a variety of situations than my original Wasteland 2 characters. I liked the plot for a while. I saved Highpool on my original Wasteland 2 playthrough, I saved Ag Center on my DC playthrough, and I liked them both. I liked the Rail Nomads, and the little hidden surprises scattered around the wasteland, including the random encounters. I especially felt good about the number of options I seemed to have for resolving a number of the situations I ran across. It felt good. It felt right. I was pretty happy.  Then I went to prison, and everything went to hell. Suddenly all my options went away. Without spoiling anything, the prison area presents you with little in terms of choices, and it is frustrating. Especially in the DC, I got to the prison with characters that had a lot of options available to them, and yet at the prison they were largely unusable. Further, the logic that the game presented behind *why* I had no options just did not follow. What's worse, the outcome at the prison seems to be the same no matter what you do there. I've searched for an explanation online, only to discover various apologists saying that the development team was trying to hammer home the idea that the wasteland is really terrible. The problem with this argument, of course, is that you do not have to take away player agency to get this point across, and yet this is what we are left with. Confusingly, in earlier versions of this game those choices did exist at the prison, and there seems to be no good explanation as to why they were taken out.  And, unfortunately this is where I had to stop playing both versions of this game. This is when it stopped feeling like a role playing game, and started feeling like a visual novel with some cosmetic combat, and not a particularly interesting or engagine one at that. Is it unfair to judge the entire game based on my experience? Maybe. But I have tried to get back the feeling I had of playing a role playing game, the one that the game still managed to engender early on in my playthroughs, but the immersion has apparently been broken irreparably.  Maybe if I hadn't seen the setting half a dozen times in other games, or if the plot were more unique and engaging, or the gameplay more interesting, or the game less frustratingly buggy, or the graphics more beautiful or the audio less . . . horrific . . . Maybe if these things had been the case it would have carried me through this immersion-breaking area and onward towards the end of the game. And maybe I will still be inspired to play through the rest of the game, experiencing it in its entirety and I will change my tune. But every time I try to play again, I am presented with the fact that my choices in the Prison area will have no impact on the game, not even any HOPE of impact, and then despair sets in and I cannot continue. Not despair over the setting or the plot. Not despair over the fates of the individuals in the Prison area who are doomed because the wasteland is a horrible place. No, my despair is over the poor design decision. I *know* that it could have been a better game, that they could have confronted us with an unforgiving area that showed us how brutal the wasteland can be without taking away our options/choices/agency. But they did not, and so I cannot recommend this game.

I really enjoyed this classic-style turn-based CRPG. Imagine something similar to the original Fallout games, but with an interface more akin to the new X-Com. You can rotate the camera and zoom-in and out. Plus, you create four characters rather than control a single hero. The skill system, quest structure, and NPC selection add greatly to the replay value.  There's also some fun writing and scenarios you'll find yourself in. It's definitely a bit gritty, but not without some humor of the dark, grossout, and lewd varieties.  It's not without faults, but in my opinion it's a great tribute to the original Wasteland and a great game on its own.

I've preordered this game, via steam, as an early backer. I can only speak for the beta, which I would give 8.5/10. This game is a tactical RPG (Think Final Fantasy Tactics, Fallout, Might & Magic) with a setting in a post-nuclear wasteland (Think Fallout, but different). The REAL spiritual 'Fallout 3', the story is a successor to Wasteland 1, but NOT a requirement to play the game, it's completely standalone. The biggest strength of this game is: The feels. Early on (15 mins) you get a choice which will immediately change the storyline in a minor way.  Over and over you will feel the sting of the game as your actions bite back in an emotional way.  Ask yourself these two questions, and then you're ready to play this game: 'Do the needs of the many really outweigh the needs of the few?' and 'If I save this man from death, how will I know he will not harm others?'  Game on, brothers and sisters.

Bring me back to the old fallout games. Old skill play, with better graphics and more stuff to play with. Definitely worth buying if you like classic rpg style games. The directors cut is ok basically the same game but some changes. I hope they make another one

I should note, that this game takes time. First 4-6 hours i wondered what's so good about it, but later it was impossible for me to stop playing, so if you're having problems with the game just try to force yourself through couple of first quests. I promise you, it gets better.   Pros: + nice and versatile story. There are several different outcomes of the main quest and each is interesting in it's own way + gameplay is good. It's turn-based and mostly depends on your positioning, gear and your character's skills + visuals are fine. Sure they're not stunning, it's not Crysis, but it'll do + tons of cool side-quests and ways of completing them. You can go in guns blazing or take a more subtle approach(es). Each choise has it's own advantages and good sides, but it's up to you to decide what to do. + interesting characters. Not all of them, of course, but mostly characters (aswell as the story) are written very good with a nice slice of humor.  + exploration is really rewarding. Game encourages you to go where you're not supposed to (like radiation clouds and other places, where you might find shrines or cache) + lots of weapons, clothes, equipment and other stuff + tons of fun easter eggs and references + is generally fun to play once you get a hang of it   Cons: - sometime it feels like the game overstays it's welcome  - some quests and their alternative ways are really not so obvious. Some people might like it that way though - it's really easy to screw up your character (try to pick 3-5 skills for each character and only level up those. Otherwise your char will be a mess)  - it's slow. Because of turn-based gameplay and lots of walking-there-doing-that some basic quests take lots of time.  What i expected: bigger-better-cooler Fallout  What i got: basically what i expected

This is my first review ever here on steam, and never has a game compelled me so much to review it as WL2, so here goes.  Short Review: This is an unfinished game. If we, as players, accept this very low bar of completion as OK, then we will reap the 'rewards'.  In-Depth Review: I think it's important to understand where this game is coming from before criticizing it. Tons of Fallout fans were less-than-impressed when Fallout 3 came out and, despite being promised something other than a re-skinned Oblivion (now Skyrim) got just that.  As such, the hype was huge for a game from the original makers crowdfunded a true sequel with tried-and-tested Firaxis on board. The target of 1 million was met and grew to 3 million dollars. The game won a GOTY award and has been well-received.  That was all I needed, so jumped in and was ready for just such an experience.  I did some reading and carefully crafted characters for the long journey ahead, nevermind thst there's very little in a tutorial to prep you. I'm seasoned gamer, so go!  So I end up roaming the wastes and get random encounters. Some I try, some I try to flee. You get 'caught', and then you're loaded into an instance. The mobs are now romaing about in the instance, not chasing you, and you get to do these a lot unless you have one skill. Same scenarios and maps. Hmmm...is this GOTY material?  Then you get into your first quest to go to X place and do Y things. Along the way, my noob party visited a much higher level area than they were fit for. Hmmm...no warning?  Luckily, we left and didn'tengage our certain death. We went on to the Ag Center. I was woefully unprepared, but managed to survive most of it...until I found myself at an impass: I had tried to crack a safe that has a critical keycard to enter one of the next areas, but I critically failed which essentially bricked the safe, which was the only place where I could get the keycard.  I went on having learned the critical rule of this game: you save about every 2 seconds and keep vast repositories of save lists. Unfortunately, I learned this after i borked the safe with the keycard. Not one to give up, I went on to other areas and did a boss fight where only 2 of my people had ammo left. After about 20 tries, we got the guy without running out of meds for people he wasted.  Now, that's what happened in the game. The combo of ridiculous bosses, minimal resources, and the CRUSHING fact that I might not get the keycard I needed nearly caused me to uninstall.  My reaction to this is now what you might expect, but it's what gets repeated ad nauseum on forums related to this game. I took this as old school. You just have to deal with your decisions. YEAH, and this makes everything more realistic, right? So I left and had my NPC surgeon Rose desert us and picked up Angela Deth, who is great and all but nobody told me i'd need her, and we progressed...  But at the same time, the clunky camera and its limited zoom functions created this 'very atmospheric' sense that I was lost. I was...and just wanting one more level of zoomout as compared to the satellite view in my inventory.  And then you go into a scenario and place your characters just like you want them as you've done a thousand times by this point: in the right position but facing walls.  And this was the point of no return. I just realized that, for all the 'difficulty' you face, the execution is just sucky. I knew that, if enough people complained, patches would fix things,but, I thought to myself for the first time ever, 'THIS is GOTY?'  I stopped blaming myself and started thinking 'these are the problems that justify the existence of play-testers.' Did anyone playtest this game before release? Not based on my experience, and forums suggest I'm not the only one who's had the same problems I've encountered.  AND AND, if you want to see this done right, X-COM does it to near perfection.   Bottom line: the game required a million dollar budget. It got 3 million. In turn, we got something that is still in beta. finished.  I don't blame players who are enjying this, but I'll never trust entities again which have chosen it as GOTY when it's not

First and foremost - THIS IS NOT FALLOUT (first nor second)! Drill this to your head. Do not buy this game thinking it's Fallout. Do not PLAY this game thinking it's Fallout. Wasteland is one thing, Fallout is something completely different. Now lets begin.  Do you like post-apocalyptic lite CRPGs? If you do then this is something you should definately check out. Now when I say 'lite' I do really mean it. This game feels, at times, extremely shallow and simplistic in everything from interactions with the environment, quests, combat and items. Everything is simplified. Yet this still is a good and enjoyable game and worth every penny you spend to buy it. The closest comparison that I can make to this game is Fallout Tactics, which in my opinion was vastly underrated and received way too much flak than it deserved, and I still rate Fallout Tactics higher than this. Character creation is based on the CLASSIC system (whereas Fallout uses SPECIAL) with just attributes and skills. No special perks or traits. You can customize your Rangers appearance, bio and so on but none of that affects your game in anyway. Combat is single squad, turn-based and squared grid layout playing field. Nothing too fancy, straightforward and to the point. You have different guns, bombs and heavy weapons with some different fire modes and ability to try a headshot. The cover system is similiar to the new XCOM Enemy Unknown game with the icon showing cover positions. Quests are typical (somewhat gliche'd) CRPG quests of fetch things, solve problems and make binary choices between factions. Environment is a bit stoic. Things you can interact with can be highlighted with a press of a key and that's about it. Game is full of easter eggs, dark humour and references. This was actually something that really started to annoy me. It feels like in every scene and place you visit is just riddled with them. I mean come on! Candy is nom noms but too much candy makes your stomach hurt.  As a whole Wasteland 2 is a good game. It's not fantastic or rebirth of CRPGs. It's just a good game. Just do not try to compare it to Fallout games. The only things these have in common are Fargo and the post-apocalyptic theme.

I might as well recommend this game now. Etiquette tells me I should wait until I've completed the game to give a full perspective, but let's face it- this game is deep enough I'll probably never get to it.  It contains all the best parts of the old text-heavy, turn-based RPGs of years ago. The isometric perspective might be nostalgic, but it works so well. There are a ton of great details that make combat fun and interesting with more than enough skills and attributes to make each point assignment a tough debate.  Perks are sadly missing. Please stop comparing this game to Fallout 1 & 2. Please stop saying things like it's 'the true Fallout 3.'  It's not. It's not even close. It lacks any and all of Fallout's whimsical charm, it forces you to create a squad at the beginning instead of striking out on a lonely, eerie struggle.  Moreover, the game feels like it's high on its own supply. Overhyped, oversold, generally just not ideal for someone who wants an original Fallout experience. There's a big difference between this super serious, staid setting and the wacky retro-future of Fallout.  Honestly, this is like a better verison of Fallout: Tactics at the end of the day. I'm not saying this is a bad game, it's just extremely misleading to compare it to the original Fallout titles. It is NOT like them. No traits, no perks, no color or humor. Not enough attribute and skill points at the beginning for an individual character, since you're supposed to make four. There's no room for character development or finding your own identity. The very first conversation, I'm pushed into saying 'sir' constantly and being a military recruit. Maybe I don't WANT to join the rangers.   Maybe I want to just run out into the wilderness or find a city hub and just make my own path - like I did in Fallout.  I realize everyone is different. But part of the reason I loved Fallout was that my companions had their own minds and I didn't have to micromanage them constantly. It ended up creating hilarious (and sometimes awful) situations in which my companions surprised me in combat. Overall, it was more immersive (to me) because I was focused entirely on my own character, instead of mysteriously mind-controlling a group.  Overall, it's hard to say whether or not I recommend the game. I know some people will love it. But I can't get over the vast disappointment after I was lead to believe, from literally everyone, that this is like Fallout. It's not. Fallout, in my opinion, is way more fun. Mechanically, aesthetically, and otherwise.  Just one woman's point of view. Take it or leave it.

Ultimately, Wasteland 2 is an average game that scratches a particular nostalgia itch for many gamers and is receiving praise beyond its merits. Quite frankly, the Turn-based strategy genre has been in a drought for nearly a decade and fans are dying of thirst to the extent they'll lap up contaminated water riddled with disease and ask for seconds. They're so enamored with a sub-standard product they don't recognize they're dying a most dishonorable death from dysentery.  Combat - The combat is lackluster and is not tactical nor strategic in any sense of the fashion. OK Corral gun duels might be more appropriate, except slow and with none of the skill involved. If you want a game with good combat, just replay XCOM2012 or Xenonauts.  Character building - No skill tree, no perks, nothing to be found except redundant skills to simply dump your stat points into every time you level up. If you're looking for the complexity and fun of a D&D style character sheet, keep looking. If you're looking for a Fallout perk system... keep looking. Even Diablo 3, which the avid fans of W2 seem keen to mock, has a far more indepth character building system.  Story - Glaring plot hole at the beginning of the game that most people seem to overlook or simply not notice. Even if you look past that, the only clever aspect of the entire game is the little Easter Eggs you'll occasionally find. However, finding kitty litter, a condom, or big black didlo for the 15th time is just sad. It's funny the first time, but like any good joke, you have to know when to quit effing telling it. If you want a game with a good story, reboot Mass Effect, BG, Fallout... pretty much any other CRPG.  Characters - Easily forgettable and none that will be remembered. No Minsc & Boo, HK-47, Commander Shepards, Irenicus (best villain ever), Tomi Grin Undergallows etc. No Delita or Ramza to be found here. For the most part, they're as bland and lifeless as the Arizona wastes you'll wander around for the first half of the game.   Exploration - Some of the environments are interesting, but with the terrible combat and random loot, much of the fun is taken out of it.  Graphics - The game wasn't trying to inspire us with graphical prowess or eye porn, but what it delivered is unpolished and ugly. Some will argue it's stylistic or gritty, but to each their own.  Sound - Ok, but no gripping musical scores to be found here.  At the end of the day, everything W2 set out to do has been done before (obviously), but done far better.

I have barely scratched the surface of Wasteland 2, but numerous people have been asking my opinion so I figured I would post a 'first impressions' review.  I came to Wasteland 2 as a Fallout 1/2 fan. The kickstarter was the first time I had heard of Wasteland so I didn't know what to expect. All I knew was that it was a combat heavy turn-based strategy game set in a nuclear wasteland. Based on the fact that 'Toaster Repair' is a useful skill made me it assume it had a healthy dose of snark as well.  When I started the game I found out it was both what I expected and entirely different. The interface was more or less exactly what I had expected. The descriptive text and conversations were a lot more detailed than anticipated, but still lived up to expectations. [WARNING: This game has swearing.]  The fact that the interface was as expected made it seem easy to jump right in and start exploring. Wow, was I wrong. The content and difficulty were another beast.  From what I've seen thus far the overall tone is best described as “Dark Attitude”. The rangers aren't lights in darkness, they are flawed individuals who find themselves in the roles of peacekeepers. Its not a game where you get thanked for helping, its one in which those you help will gripe about it taking too long to get there and generally be jerks. Fellow Fallout fans should be prepared for a very different tone.   Contrary to what I expected it was not easy to jump in. I had chosen a party of pregenned characters, thinking they were relatively balanced, and was proven very wrong. This became very obvious in the Ag Center and led to me restarting. Chance to hit was low, ammo usage was high, and eventually I was running around punching everything with characters spec’ed for ranged combat. If you don’t explore everywhere and carefully manage your ammo, you are in for a hard time. Don’t forget your shovel, safe-cracker, and toaster repair expert!  Despite, or perhaps because of, the difficulty, I find myself continually thinking about the game and wondering what is next. If you like turn based combat and don’t mind having to work for victory it is worth getting. Just don’t go in expecting a Fallout clone because its an entirely different game.

So my recommendation is: if the style of game appeals to you, get it (preferably in some kind of sale), but wait with playing until the bugs are ironed out. Let me begin by saying that Wasteland 2 is not like Fallout outside of the post-apocalyptic theme, and a few design choices. Wasteland 2 is a great game, but it is not as good as Fallout 2.   The game is a good squad-based RPG that reminds me heavily of those old Fallout games, though. And indeed, I love this game much the same. There is a variety of ways you can solve most of your problems, and because of that, this game has consumed what has to have been over 10 hours of my life already.   There are some problems I have with the game. And if this game were made by any other unknown indie developer, I would have rolled my eyes and moved on. But this game was made by Brian Fargo, with help from several other veterans of good old RPGs that we knew and love, so this makes me disappointed at a few design choices.  1. A few skills are a bit too divided. Unnecessarily so. Why is Safecracking and Lockpicking two different skills? Why not just make Safes harder to lockpick? Why are Blunt Weapons and Bladed weapons separate? What was so wrong with a general 'melee' skill? Why is there a skill just for modding weapons? Who in their right mind would put skill points into Toaster Repair? While some skill divisions made logical sense -- obviously, in a squad-based RPG, a generic 'guns' skill would be broken, and speech is basically divided into what you want to accomplish with words (Reasoning, Seduction, or Intimidation). But I honestly think Weapon Modding should have been covered by Mechanical Repair, and Safes should fall under Lockpicking.  1a. And while I am at it, what is the point of the Demolitions skill outside of trap disarming? All explosive weapons are disposable, one-use items (REAAAAALLY dislike, by the way), and none of them are affected by your skill at handling explosives. Instead, grenades and bombs are handled XCOM: Enemy Unknown style -- click where you want the bomb to go and the character tosses it, with little chance of error. Now, I loved XCOM, but what the hell? No grenade launchers with appropriate ammo? No rockets for your LAWs and RPGs? No mines? (well, the ENEMY can place mines, but you can't). No C-4? Why have Demolitions at all, outside of defusing the numerous (frankly obnoxious) traps inside every other box of loot?  2. No Stealth mechanic or skill. This hit me pretty hard when I realized there was no stealth in the game, because I am all about conflict avoidance in RPGs. I am the kind of guy whose priority in Fallout New Vegas was getting my speech to 100 -- the fewer bullets I fire during a quest, the better. Not to mention there were several situations I ran into that practically BEGGED for the usage of stealth, and yet, it simply wasn't possible.   Aside from that though, the game seems to be doing well in the 'cause and effect' aspect that many RPGs sorely lack. There are tough decisions you will find yourself making as you journey across the wasteland. The best solutions that benefit everyone often require large amounts of skill in the required talents -- Unless you specialize your rangers, you aren't going to do many great things. It's a good RPG. And honestly, it has me hooked. But damnit, I DID expect better.  I do recommend it though, despite its flaws. The game itself is good, it's just that I did not expect to find the flaws I did from veterans of the industry. If you liked Wasteland, and you liked Fallout 1 and 2, check it out. Of course, I must stress this -- it is NOT Fallout. Don't get the game expecting Fallout.

I found the game to have serious game design flaws that make me regret the purchase. May this be a warning to others.  First there is way to much useless clicking involved. For example: characters don't just level up, one needs to call in to HQ then pretend to read the useless exchange with the caption then click through a series of boring dialog options only then can one go to assking skill points. Seriously I was annoyed by this even the first time around. You have to do this each time a character levels up ...  Here is another: assigning an item to a hotkey is not just dragging the item into the hotkey slot, you have to right click the item (even though the help says right-click to use, you have to disregard that) then click the assign hot key then click the hotkey. The interfaces are a little sluggish so you won't be clicking all that fast either.  Maps: The maps are tiny, cramped and sluggish. One seemingly needs to always rotate the map back and forth not to miss a detail. There is always another zone to load there is no sense of exploration or adventure. All the background are prerendered and non mostly non destructible. It is very difficult to figure out quest objectives - some objects are 'indestructible' until some quest objective is finished but still show up as targetable - so you end up wasting ammo on them.   Combat: The game interface is unforgiving in combat - it is hard to tell which character is in LOS of another thus in danger to get into a friendly fire incident. In short, Wasteland 2 tells a story about what you cannot do - open doors, chests or safes, hit enemies or talk cunningly. Mostly at the beginning of the game to be fair, but even later on there are several objects to interact with that often cause you to fail critically when using a maxed out skill on them. You then either have to accept this and carry on or load a previous save game and try again.  Given the fact that the loot often is not worth the trouble, option 1 should be the way to go (or ignore the possible loot in the fist place), but that's not what I expect of a game. Reloading (and again and again sometimes) is a slow and tedious process. May be I'm not getting the point and Wasteland 2 then is not the game for me, but on the other hand this is a personal review and all about how I like it.  There's more boring stuff in it, like quests which have you to visit the same places a few times over without the possibility to quick travel. Given the size and layout of some areas and the way they are connected to other areas sometimes causes you to sit there for minutes and tell your team to go back and forth. That's a way of extending the play time. One I don't like at all. Especially if the quest giver sends you more often than needed to the same place when all that has to be done could have easily been accomplished on the first visit.  Personally I didn't care much for the story. Cannot really identify the cause though. I found myself mostly rushing through the dialog options, only scanning for relevant key words to get through quickly - which is a shame because I think the writing itself seems to be fine. But I couldn't connect the the world like I did when playing Fallout 1 and 2 for example. In the end I tried to solve all open quests and finish the story so I could mark this game as completed.  Technically I had severe performance issues in some (mostly indoor) areas on my Linux machine and encountered several bugs. The Linux version of Borderlands 2 for example runs much better here.  I'm not saying Wasteland 2 is a bad game. Most people seem to like it. But you have to tolerate a couple of things which just annoy me to the point the fun gets significantly spoiled. All in all I'm too disappointed to recommend this game.

To start, if anyone is having crashing problems on WIN 10, type -force-d3d9 into launch options on Steam. Haven't had a single crash after that.  About the game, Wasteland 2 is not for everyone. Not by a long shot. It requires patience, thinking and in some cases, nerves of steel. The top-down view and turn-based combat may turn some people off. It's a hardcore RPG where your choices, starting from the very beginning at character creation, have lasting consequences throughout the game. If you're looking for an experience similar to the more recent Fallout games, you won't find it here.  The character creation is intimidating at first, especially for newcomers to these types of games. There are tons of skills and you have no way to know in advance which are useful and which are more situational. I suggest consulting a character creation guide, but if you want to do everything on your own, one tip: make a team of specialists. After character creation, it's good to keep in mind these three things: Talk to EVERYONE, LOOT everything that isn't bolted down (or if it is, Brute Force can help with that ;)) and do EVERYTHING you can before moving to the next area. If you miss something, it might mean missing out on quests, companions or loot.  The combat is tactical and turn-based. Director's Cut added precision strikes, which are not too useful at the beginning but can be lifesavers late in the game. It also brough some flavor to the combat system, which can be somewhat tedious at times. I found most of the quirks to be quite useless; their downsides were either too bad or they were too situational. Same goes for perks, they were a nice addition, but when selecting perks I had difficulty finding ones that were actually useful. Overall, precision strikes, quirks and perks feel somewhat like an aftertought; they're there and they're nice to have every once in a while, but they aren't really crucial to completing the game.  The weapon rebalancing of DC was a welcome addition. Assault rifles and Snipers are still king, but Shotguns, for example, now actually have some use. SMG's and Handguns still suck, though.  Overall, I definitely recommend this game to everyone. While it can be somewhat tedious and difficult at times, it's still a whole lot of fun. The world is huge and there's plenty to do, like blowing off the heads of raiders or solving feuds peacefully. BUT DON'T PRESS THE BUTTON AT RANGER CITADEL!

Let me tell you about Wasteland 2.  I was out on a mission after having managed to strike a truce with a potential enemy who'd already flattened my crew more than once. The guy who tried to land the Desert Rangers in trouble with them is scared for his life because I dobbed him in as the true culprit - even after he helped me put things right, even after I said I wouldn't. He runs off to get his scaly mates all wound up and ready to make trouble.  I think about it for a split second then headshot the stupid bugger. He can have his little hissyfit, but there's no way he's stuffing up this unexpected and welcome truce, Not while my sniper's rifle is loaded.  Then I realise the effect this game is having on me. I'm horrified with myself. I rationalise the decision: the guy was too dumb to live; he'd have only got more innocent people killed; he was trying to covertly start fights he couldn't finish; at least if I put him down like this the other mob wouldn't torture him to death or something. I'm even more horrified at the rationalisations. I wonder if the game even has an event path for what I just did. Would his friends jump me next time because of a bug, or did he need to actually make it back to his friends to trigger that situation? Would there still be a truce when I got back? Did I really take care of the problem?   The problem. Huh. That problem had a name. And friends. Possibly a family.  This game is getting me to play like an amoral hardcase for the first time ever (usually I do my best to be a good guy) - and I simultaneously love it and fear it for that. Not because it's fun but because everything is a moral grey area, every success has a bit of failure in it, and it's rare for everyone to make it out alive and unscathed.  10/10

So, if you take the term 'CRPG' really seriously and enjoy getting in fights about how modern RPGs aren't 'real' RPGs, and you wish it were still the late 1990s, this is a great game for you and you don't need to read the rest of my review.  On the other hand, if you enjoy isometric party-based RPGs but also might like to see some progress from the last 15 years or so of gaming history, Wasteland 2 is kind of a letdown precisely because of how stubbornly it emulates the UI fiddliness of Fallout 1/2. Get ready to remember which party member owns a shovel, switch to them, activate the shovel item, and wait while a progress bar fills up, every time you want to dig something up. And this isn't just shovels, it's *every specialized skill*. You're not realistically going to put together a party with more than one girl or guy who knows Safecracking or some other random ♥♥♥♥, but the game will never let you just click on the safe and have the one Safecracker open it.  The maps suffer from a similar level of fiddliness. You will have to memorize where in town that random questgiver is, or come back from a fetch quest to wander all over wondering where his shop is among a town of identical-looking dwellings. No quest markers is fine, I don't think that the player should have telepathic knowledge of where stuff is ahead of time, but when you're looking to turn in quests (and the characters would already know where shopkeeper X is) it's just a hassle. Isometric design also means that the level designers hide crates in places where you need to rotate the camera to find them ... which is fine, but after a while, it's not clever, it's just irritating to have to rotate the camera every time you enter a new room or potentially miss out on loot.  I could go on with examples of the weird sort of micromanagement that Wasteland 2 requires of the player (there are many more), but you get the point.  Bottom line, it feels like a game that came out in 2000, not 2014. If you're fine with this, go ahead and get it (but you probably already did). If you're not, and especially if you haven't played Fallout 1/2 to death, there's really no reason to play this instead of Fallout 1/2.

TL;DR: Decent story, interesting world, mediocre dialogues. Relatively boring battles/gameplay. Decent sound and graphics, but limited customization and very ugly character models. Would have fared better without the high expectations from the kickstarter. Close to a positive recommendation, but not quite: 5/10.  The sequel to the inspiration for Fallout... talk about high expectations. Add to this the fact that it was a super-successful Kickstarter project that promised to put the creative people back in charge of their own projects, and it's easy to see why so many hopes for the future of PC roleplaying rest(ed) on this game. I found it somewhat disappointing in many details small and large, unfortunately. Would I have liked it without the hype? I will never know. Does it matter for this review? No. A game that carries so much baggage needs to be reviewed with it in mind.   Story/World:  Meh. As so often, it is difficult to say anything without too many spoilers. The world is an... interesting place. Unlike Fallout, it places less emphasis on realism and does not take itself too seriously, allowing for some weird and fascinating factions and places, which are fun to explore. Unfortunately, while there are some gems, the size of the world means that no place has much depth and really catches your heart. Did I feel at home and connected to Ranger Citadel? No. Did I care that a lot of old acquaintances showed up, helped and died in the final battle? No. Did I really care for the epilogues for the places I had visited? No. So: While the game presents a varied and interesting world, it failed to pull me in.  Additionally, they sat a bit heavily on the predecessor (old characters, old locations, old stories that are repeated again and again) which I did not play, making it hard for me to get invested.  Dialogues were a mixed bag as well. Some good, but also a lot of repetition of the same pieces of information over and over again.  The roleplaying came down to a handful of choices (Do I help this person? Which of those two factions do I support?). My characters lacked, unfortunately, a character.  The main story is actually very short. Weird robots show up. Now go and fight them. It's nice and consistent, without plot holes, but the ending    not only digs out the Big Bad from part one, but also uses the Terminator reasoning for the nuclear war, which seems lazy.     Sound:  Nice enough, but could have been more varied.  Graphics:  I usually don't care too much about graphics, but some things really disturbed me here from the very beginning. Character models are  ugly . What's more, there are a very limited number of character portraits, all of which are used as NPC portraits as well, so you quite often have two identically-looking people talking to each other. Finally, the descriptions of characters in the world very often don't match their portrait at all. Takes me out of the story.  That said, the maps are done with great care and are quite beautiful.  Gameplay:  Yeah... that was what almost made me give up on the game in between. There are a few minor things that bugged me (area map is a screenshot, allows no notes, shows no locations), but the big thing is the combat. This is where you spend most of your game.  But  the combat is pretty damn  boring : There is a basic cover mechanic, but many places in which you will find yourself starting battles are devoid of cover at least for your group. Thus, many battles end up being about choosing who to shoot. Throw in some small-ish things like unclear sight lines/weapon ranges especially when the battle goes over two levels and the whole affair becomes less an intricate chess game between you and the (mediocre) AI and more a tedious excercise in mopping up without using too many resources.  Then there are the crates. And the safes. And the holes. And the toasters. Everything wants to give you items, which are absolutely necessary in the beginning and absolutely superfluous in the end. But if you're anything like me, you will STILL open the next safe - just in case of the very occasional plot-relevant item. Makes the game go even slower and becomes, at times, an excercise in quick-saving and quick-loading.  Finally, while the game throws loads of skills at you, there is no deep character building here. One weapon skill, one auxiliary skill (or three for the skill monkeys) per person, done.  In summary, while the game amused me and made me smile at times, it did not make me think and it did not make me care for its world or characters. At least one of those I expect from a roleplaying game. Thus: Not recommended.  Addendum: Reading it again, this review sounds exceptionally negative. It wasn't really meant to be; most of the issues I mentioned bothered me, but not as much as in other games. It's just that a lot of things that don't bother me too much add up to make this game pretty mediocre - maybe 5/10.

Wasteland 2 was one of those games that really speaks to older generations of games. There are many good as well as bad design features, but overall it's an enjoyable experience if you're willing to put yourself through it.   Upon starting up your first game you create a party of four Rangers and can choose their stats and skills, select character appearance options, and write a quick bio should you so desire. Of course, one of the things that is limited by the standards of old crpgs is that you can't play your character too far off the path of the desert rangers, but still the story is interesting and features a lot of unique ideas that might just get you to crack a smile.   Now there is a ton of dialogue and text in this game, but of course that means a lot of conversation options come up time after time. You'll find your self clicking things to get them out of the way, and of course sometimes this can get you into confrontations without any clear indications. Since I like to schmooze my way through many of these it was kind of annoying that there werent more options to use the skills associated with conversation, but at least they were there.   The combat mechanics were probably the most fun. I played this game at the second highest difficulty on my first try and didn't have too much trouble. There are some frustrating things, like enemies walking 150 tiles across the map straight up to your characters on the first turn and punching them in the face, but so long as you're prepared you can usually deal with this by lobbing out grenades and rockets. That being said, there are plenty of different weapons to take advantage of and they are all useful and unique in different ways. Some character stats are more useful to combat than others, so it helps a ton to diversify your party because the situations that arise require different skills and weapons. Some enemies are tough to take out with light weapons, but easy targets with energy guns, and vice versa.   As a piece of advice you will be binding quick save to the key closest to your keyboard hand, and pressing it often. There are times where it is not always clear what you have to do, and if you do them in the wrong order you can get into situations like endless combat for HOURS before you give up and reload. It's truly unfortunate that unorthodox situations do this to the player, as it feels restricting at times. I remember early in the game trying to expedite a mayoral race, and did as many helpful tasks as I could save for one that I could not find. Turns out the doctor, who said he didn't need any help, actually needec you to use your surgeon skill on his patients... seriously? I spent hours trying to figure this out before looking it up.   Another gripe is that you will spend hours just walking across maps, for no purpouse other than you're going back and fourth for quests. There are sometimes ways around this that open up after having done enough to open up a quicker passage, but usually by this point it doesn't even matter anymore. You'll experience this enough to come to hate the experience. You'll be getting out your chair to find something to distract you for three minutes while your party walks around, and sometimes you have no idea if where you're going is going to help your quest. Truly this was the most frustrating aspect of the game.   Yet another thing, many characters have the same portraits, even important ones at times. I really wish that they had taken the Baldurs Gate appreach and only gave important characters unique portraits. And the portraits, they look like they were painted by a college student. They werent bad, but felt lacking. Sometimes it made the characters you meet less unique, as they just sort of blend into each other.   Now it might seem i'm going off on the negative aspects of the game, but these are things you should know before you start playing. It's by no means perfect, but hightly enjoyable. This game is XCOM meets Fallout. It has the dark humour and post-apocalyptic setting of the Fallout series, with the punishing, perma-death combat of the XCOM series.  The graphics aren't amazing, but they're adequate for the game style. The music is atmospheric, the writing is fun, and the voice acting is hit-or-miss.  The gameplay is great for people who like this sort of turn-based squad combat. All the usual elements are here: objects in the environment provide cover, hits are percent-based, and actions cost AP to execute, which replenishes each turn.  My only real complaint is the navigation on the overworld map, which seems like a cop-out from making an interesting overworld. Whenever you aren't in an encounter area (random encounter, dungeon, town), your party is represented as a marker on a huge map of the American Southwest, which will slowly move toward your destination in the way Indiana Jones travels-- a line drawn on the map.  It's fun to create characters, and the combat is challenging but rewarding.  Well worth the purchase price.

Wasteland 2 is a throwback to the classic Fallout and Fallout 2 games set in a different but rather similar post-apocalyptic setting. I want to like this one. I've gotten big into CRPGs lately. Pros: - Excellent story and design. I loved how you have to choose right away between two different areas and it completely changes the story based on which one you pick.  - Extensive character customization. This may well be the first game set on Earth that actually lets you choose both your nationality and religion. Dunno if that actually DOES anything, but its neat.  - Crafting, modding, and so on is ready from the word go (provided one of your guys is a weaponsmith) and you can immediately use any mods you get.  Cons: - The combat is horribly stacked against you even on the lowest difficutly. Here's a quick rundown of the issues I had with it:  - I want it to be a rule in games like this that if you have ranged combat, whether its guns or bows or whatever, that your BASIC ammo is unlimited. Especially, and I mean ESPECIALLY, when one of the first areas you go to has zombies that explode upon death and plants that burst the second you get near them. The only way to get past those without getting hurt was to shoot them, which eats up ammo very quickly.  - Some of the fights are so stacked against you it's painful. I get that people want a good fight, but when my four guys are up against four raiders with assault rifles, two throwing dynamite, two more with pistols, and one big ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a machine gun in the same fight I might begin to think that this game's difficulty needs to be adjusted a bit. Yes it does come with difficulty settings but here's the thing: I WAS PLAYING ON ROOKIE WHEN THIS HAPPENED! I'm not asking for a free ride here, but for ♥♥♥♥'s sake I did that fight three times and each time my entire team got wiped out within a few rounds because our half of the battlefield is narrow and, again, TWO GUYS THROW BOMBS AT US!  - It seems like my guys miss a hell of a lot. My team had one guy who specialized in energy weapons, one who was good with pistols, another who used shotguns, and a melee specialist. No matter what though, even with crouching, I could sometimes only get about 50% hit chance even at point blank range and this was with them having most of their points in that weapon type.  - Status effects for everyone! 3/5  I've been playing Wasteland 2 and feeling a little disappointed. It's too retro.  The pacing is on the slow side, and it's not the best-looking game.  OK, it's set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland, but character designs and backgrounds can still look good. Like, the environments of Bethesda's Fallout 3 were dramatic and beautiful even if they were all drab gray ruins. My performance should not be this poor for a game that looks like this.  And the skill use is just a touch too slow. If one needs to save-load-spam to get past a lock, or if there are a lot of mines to disarm, it's tedious.  And the combat does not feel as dynamic and tactical as, say, the X-Com remake's. There's really only 2 options: headshot and burst, otherwise one crouches the team and shoots and that's it for tactics. X-Com's system encouraged much more movement and flanking, as well as having special abilities by class that affect tactics. And of course, Divinity: Original Sin introduces a lot of tricks with spell interactions that can control the battlefield, or that rapidly move characters around the battlefield. Compared to X-Com and D:OS, the combat in W2 feels primitive.   Also, it REALLY needs formation options. It's damn tedious having to individually click on the characters to spread them out before triggering combat. Most of the time I just have them clustered up non-optimally because I can get away with it, but it would have been nice if there were Baldur's Gate style formations. If there is an option for this and I'm just too slack to find it in the interface, please, tell me.  If I hadn't played Divinity: Original Sin or X-Com, I would probably really enjoy Wasteland 2. It's still a decent game, but it feels like D:OS just does it better. It's prettier, the combat is more fun, the pacing is better....  Wasteland 2 feels like there was a little too much old-school thinking limiting their design decisions.  And some of the mechanics just plain feel WEIRD. Like how disconnected attributes are from skill use. Or the way energy weapons work with armor. There should NEVER be a situation where it's better to have lower armor, that's just dumb.  Plus there are too many skills that cover similar things like lockpick + safecracaking, 3 skills all covering dialogue, etc. Do shotguns, rifles, sniper rifles, smgs really all need separate skills? It ought to just be small arms, long arms, energy weapons and heavy. It seems COMPLETELY random that toaster repair requires its own skill.   Normally, I'd still recommend this game as it's still above average, but there are SO many great games out or soon to be out; I would hold this purchase until it's on sale.  I'm frankly astonished at how many people seem to love it. I mean, it's okay, and I'm still going to finish it, but they write like they love it. Did they not also play Divinity: Original Sin, an also crowdfunded game that is superior in nearly every way? I loved the old school rpgs too (the Fallout games, the Infinity Engine games, the gold box games), but a great deal of the good feelings around this game seem to be driven by nostalgia more than what it actually delivers.

Wow. Think about a mix between Fallout 1/2 and Tactics (an actually good Tactics).   You probably will like this game if: - you enjoyed Wasteland 1 back then - you like turn based combat but don't expect it to be like in Jagged Alliance 2 - you like Fallout 1 or 2 or Tactics - you like post-apokalyptic themes  You probably won't like this game if: - you need state-of-the-art graphics and staged stories like in Mass Effect - you expect without exception a Fallout 2.5  You have bit less freedom than in Fallout 1 & 2 but much more than in Tactics. The turn based combat offer many options but doesn't complicate things (think of XCOM:EU/EW, when it comes down to simplicity; not much micromanagement) so it keeps up the pace and therefore the fun! Combat can also be really hard on higher difficulties since there are some medical conditions you can get (e.g. concussion, blood loss, etc.) much more frequently than in Fallout 1 &2 (it was very rare to get hurt in the eyes, legs or arms). While the combat and interface mechanics are simple there are a lot of options, skills and abilities, e.g. to spot a trap on a door you need to activate your skill 'perception' and it must be high enough. Spotting a trap is one thing but disarming is another thing that require the specific skill. In Fallout there were some skill with little or almost no use like Science but not so in Wasteland 2. Every skill you can learn can be used and some skills that seem irrelevant at first might even used in the first hour (like repairing toasters!).  Do you know the tactical RPG The Fall: Last Days of Gaia? If yes think about Wasteland 2 like a next gen and well crafted and balanced version of The Fall (and Fallout Tactics). Everything just works, quests which appear pretty straight forward and easy at first may open up and get more complicated or leads you further than you have expected (think about Vampire: Bloodlines or The Witcher 1) The German version has some troubles with the translation here and there (few parts are poorly translated or not at all) so this may apply to other languages then English, too.  The soundtrack does really make you think you're in Wasteland 1 or Fallout 1. It's just well fitting and while depressing it really makes you enjoy and recognize the soundtrack deliberately.  I wish there were more customization options for the character creation but you can use custom portraits like back in the old days of Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate. Since you probably use a camera angle with further distance it's not a big problem.  The price for this game retail is 30 bucks and for 40 you'll get the Ranger Edition in an amazing looking box with nice additional physical content (plus the Soundtrack from Wasteland 1 and 2). So you get more for your money than with many other triple A titles nowadays, physically and virtual.

Ok, so I'm 20 hours in (according to Steam), and I've owned the game for less than 2 days. Was Wasteland 2 worth it for me? I'd say so. I like complex, difficult games. Should YOU buy it? I'm not so sure. I'd give the game a 8/10 so far, but I can't recommend it to everyone. I'll breifly give you some points of reference to understand the game, and then I'll go over some more detailed points to explain why I feel the game rates an 8. Also, I did not judge the game on it's graphics. If that's what's important to you there's a massive line-up of AAA titles out there right now that will blow up your computer. W2 is not one of them. If you like XCOM Enemy Uknown/Within, then you should understand how combat works, yet the combat in W2 is much slower than in XCOM. This is, in large part, due to the depth of W2's combat system. I'll go over some of those points in a minute, but suffice to say that most of the important parts of combat are never explained, or poorly explained. The are intuitive, and they make sense, but the learning curve is far steeper than XCOM, for sure. As far as the story goes, well, the story of XCOM is told in your own head and in the moment to moment action (especially after you've played the game for hundreds of cumilitive hours), while in W2 the majority of the story is told in conversations. It's actually very similar to KOTOR or Fallout 3 in that the combat takes less than half of your playtime. Maybe even less. Unless you skip all the conversations in W2, which I imagine many players will. I fear, however, that the game loses much of its charm and drive if you don't pay attention to the written dialogue. I just think that most players aren't playing a video game to read massive amounts of text, even thought the writing is done rather well and I personally enjoy it. But then I enjoy reading and writing in my spare time, which is not representative of the average gamer. I imagine the replayability to be very high, however, since after 20 hours I'm already regretting my character builds and wishing I'd done things differently. But I'm still in the bottom quarter of the world map, and barely past level 10 with my main charaters. Even with up to seven people in your party you can't possibly have all the necessary skills for every given situation, which is both cool and frustrating. For example, your first companion, Deth, is a complete badass, and quite overpowered, and 20 hours in she is still in my party. She was essential at the beginning, yet she made one of my 4 custom charaters basically obselete. I diversified later, but unlike in XCOM, you can't switch out one of your 4 primary soldiers until one of them dies. I even purposely killed my melee warior because in the end I found him useless. Down the line you can flesh out your team somewhat using the 3 additional party slots, but it bums me out that their stories are more fleshed out than the 4 custom charaters I spent an hour making. The game truly does throw you in the deep end make you figure things out on your own. For example, does the Demolitions skill make you more proficient with exlosives? No. Apparently anyone can use explosives fairly well without training. What the demolitions skill allows you to do is disarm explosive traps. Not seeing the traps that keep on exploding in your face, even in the early game? Well, that's because you need to level up your perception skill. 'But I made sure my Awarenes skill is at Max!' you may say. Tough luck, you should have invested that in intelligence so you'd have more skill points after each level to upgrade your Perception skill. Which is a passive ability, byt the way, but you NEED TO TURN IT ON. According to Wasteland 2 and every dictionary ever Perception and Awareness mean very different things. But in the context of most video games some may think they are interchangable or at least related. In W2 they're not. This game doesn't hold your hand. This symbiosis or abilities does play out in fun and intersting ways, however. A simple example is when you break a safe while trying to crack it, you can repair it with the mechanical repair skill and try to crack it again. If you detect a boobytrapped door you can Percieve the mine, use the Demolition skill to disarm the explosive trap, then try to pick the lock, fail and set off an alarm, then use another skill to deactivate the alarm, while simultaneously smashing the broken door in with brute force. Moments like that are cool, though really only present in the more scripted story missions. Also, believe it or not, in the middle of combat you can see all the information you need about your currently equiped weapon just by hovering your mouse over certain areas to generate tooltips. It wasn't until 10 hours in that i finally found out that's where you find out your weapon's optimum range - float your mouse over the bar with mini arrows just aove the gun portrait. I could also have checked the weapon in my inventory, but who has the time for all that? Also, armor is poorly explained, so I'll explain it to you. Armor does not lessen damage taken in the traditional may like add HP or subtract from incoming damage. What it does is lessen the damage from weapons with lower armor penetration. A badass looking weapon may suck against everyone but the most basic of enemies if it has low armor penetration. That expensive new assault rifle doesn't look like much of an upgrade? Guess again, if it penetrates even ONE MORE armor layer. Seriously. I'll give you a hypothetical example. Lets say you have 2 characters weilding hypothetical pistols that both do 20-25 base damage. One of the pistols has 1 armor penetration while the other has 5. Now let's say a wolf with 1 armor ran at your two characters, and both your charaters shoots it. Both guns would do 20-30 damage. Now a human comes along, but he has 3 armor. This time the two guns do 5-8 and 20-30 damage. Huge difference, right? Now if you send that team against an enemy with 5 armor one of your soldiers will still be doing a solid 20-30 damage, but the second will be doing 1 damage every time. I barely won a few tough fights because I didn't grasp this for a long while. Honestly, I feel like I can write a guide about this game, and I'm sure there are guides out there. Yet I'd say that less than half of the people who may have tried to read this review have reached this far. In my opinion those poeple shouldn't buy the game. If you didn't have the patience to read this review, then the odds are you will not have the patience for the game. If you have completed this review, and I haven't turned you off from playing it, then follow my lead and buy it. It's pretty good. I like XCOM better, but in some ways the two games are like apples and oranges. Good thing I like both.

Wasteland 2 throws you into post-apocalyptic turn-based combat.    The story isn't anything new; a land being ravaged, once again, by a robot army. The story flows nicely, being held up by interesting characters and a variety of environments which you explore. As the setting begins to become stale, you are thrown into a new part of post-apocalyptic America to continue your journey.    Leading a squad you have created through each new location of the game, the areas and enemies change frequently enough that it all feels new. With the different combinations of weapons and skills for your characters moving you forward to the next slew of combat.    Combat is strong in this game. The variety in your strategy is determined by the development of your characters and the new enemies thrown your way. Whether keeping a sniper in cover on a hilltop or rushing forward a bruiser with a crowbar, there is plenty of variety inbetween. Any combat scenario you encounter can be approached in a number of different ways.    If you enjoy post-apocalyptic landscapes and turn-based RPG's, buy this game.
