Rewiews keep telling that this game is like Fallout, and this is very much untrue.   I remember walking by a small village made of junk and rust, treading heavily in my power armor. Children were playing around, and the wasteland sun was shining. One kid threw a stone at me, it clancked off my shoulder plate. I decided to play along, picked that stone up and threw back at the kid, my hand accelerated with well-oiled X-series power armor motors. The stone went right through kid's body, he screamed and fell into a puddle of his own blood and entrails. Suddenly i became an all-hated child murdering psycho, but what did i care, i had a Bozar on my back, helload of ammo and iguana on a stick. Terrified villagers heard my helmet-muffled whistling as i walked away, towards the white wasteland sun and new exciting adventures.   That's one of my many Fallout memories, and the only memory that Wasteland 2 left is gosh that sucked.   Wasteland 2 is on a level of really good tablet or smartphone game. It's built on awful Unity engine, which screams lazyness, it has a tablet-level dumb combat system, bland graphics with no textures, you name it...  The plot and setting are extremely uninspired, if you are a veteran of Fallout franchise, you will feel a very strong deja vu.  Mutant plants on a food growing facility? Nuclear bomb worshipping fanatics? Robot army? Raiders? Fanatics preserving technology? List could go on but i didn't make it to the end of the game.   Quest system is tedious and lacks logic. I remember doing a lot of quests to make peace between two gangs in some village, even did some not obvious things, like disarming bomb on a bycicle quickly, but in the end they still shot each other, i checked on the internet and realized it's all because i didn't kill(on purpose) some drugs producing guy, who had nothing to do with the rivalry!   Though i liked some non-obvious thing in game, like strange creature in a cell which asks for candy, strange person standing in a pointless location, it's very rare in modern quest markered games with no mystery to them.   Overall, i don't recommend this game to Fallout fans, because it's nothing like it.

I'm only a few hours in the game, but don't plan to stop anytime soon. I'll be completely honest, it's a flawed game with bugs applenty (none-game breaking) and with a kinda wonky interface that takes time to get used to. It's a super slow game that takes time to get into and that doesn't have an overload on story (no SAVE THE WORLD kinda plot here, it's smaller and a more personal story). It's the most fantastically frustrating game I own, where when I see a '81% to hit' stat I can safely assume I'll miss, or the gun will jam, or I'll hit a friendly... or any other number of things that will go wrong.  Because in this game, if it can go wrong it absolutely will. Guns with a 1-3% jam rate seem to jam every other turn. Squad members with excellent skills in markmanship (handguns/etc.) will miss far more often than they hit.   In Wasteland 2, you will spend 10 minutes disarming a trap and unlocking a safe only to find absolute junk inside. Reload to try it again and you'll find a shiny new sniper rifle instead.  It's hilarious: I've never been so frustrated with a game that I couldn't stop playing.   As addicting as Fallout/Fallout 2, as frustrating as trying to tame a hyperactive six year old in a toy store.   Guns jam with staggering frequency. A gun that says it has a 5% jam rate? Try 45%. Seriously. In one firefight, where each of my squad members had a 75% or higher change to hit, not a single round hit the enermy... FOR THREE TURNS. It was incredible. I've never seen such a ridiculous display of gunnery incompetence...  Until my 98% to hit point-blank pistol shot went awry. Not once. Not twice. Thrice.   Wasteland 2 will punish you for even thinking that you have a chance. If you don't learn that F9 must be pressed before ANY action you will not progres. Your characters will miss the enemy, repeatedly shoot themselves, and somehow manage to catestrophically fail digging up something from the ground... resulting in two fresh bodies for the Arizona wastes to reclaim.  You will quickly learn that the only thing that Wasteland 2 is honest to you about is that there are a lot of things out there trying to kill you, including the mechanics of the game itself.  But it isn't all bad. When things go right it can be a lot of fun. The graphics are pretty good. The story is even better. And hey, you're playing a RPG about a post-apocalyptic America- no kidding your guns are going to miss every other shot.

I wanted to love this game, sooooo much. I don't, but I like it. It's good, it's definitely worth playing, but this comes with some serious reservations.  First, the good: the range of options is nothing short of amazing. The return to the old model of some voice to augment mostly written dialogue clearly gave them huge amount of freedom, and I love the way the decisions *feel* like actual decisions, and not just 'Good guy / Bad guy' inane dichotomy decisions. No decision ever feels like the ideal one, and that's both difficult to execute and brilliant when done properly. The writing, by and large, is top notch.  The bad: It's very easy to create characters who end up as basically trash, and you almost have to play through once to know what you're going to need. Both your skills and attributes are locked once you select them. Skills you can make up for if you learn quickly, but you attribute allocation is pretty much locked once you create a character. Specializing in skills is hugely important if you don't want to save scum your way through all of the unlockables, but without knowing what NPCs are going to become available you can end up with very annoying redundancies. Given that a significant number of the skills are basically 'unlock X,' it starts to feel sort of silly.  The worst part, unfortunately, is the combat. It feels old, and not in a good way. For any fight that isn't a faceroll, you'll want to position your team before engaging and get it the first shot, guaranteeing your team at least some of the initiatve. Problem is, doing this is clunky to say the least. On top of that, cover (fairly necessary to keep fights from just being a straight up numbers game) is sparse and spread far apart most of the time...far enough that it's generally impossible to have more than a couple of your team in decent position. This problem is exacerbated by the weapon group disparity--ARs and sniper rifles (and occasionally energy weapons) completely outclass other weapon groups, a gap that only gets wider as the game goes on (although I will admit that my hand-to-hand bruiser does well, circumstantially). Maybe this is because I'm playing on hard, but enemies seem to have double or triple the action points of characters, allowing them to run obscene distances in a single turn or fire twice as much as characters.   The game relies heavily on combat, and for the style if play it's going for I felt like it was Jagged Alliace II lite. It uses almost all of the same systems JA2 does, but with less depth, or like X-Com, but with worse map design (for combat purposes--they're beautiful).   To clarify, this isn't a complaint that it's too hard--I *like* hard--it's that it's boring. There simply aren't a lot of options in the course of fighting and some skill and weapon choices, it becomes clear as you progress, are simply superior.   Short version: Everything about this game feels brilliant--writing, world, the player choices--but the simple / punishing combat model enourages simplicity and min/maxing in a way that takes away from the rest of the game.  So, worth buying and playing, but (and this is the first time I think I've ever said this) play it on easy or normal. Because the fighting is bland and making it harder just makes it take longer to get to the parts of the game worth playing.

I played the original Wasteland as a kid, and it still remains one of my favorite games of all time. I've been considering buying this game, but was a little worried that a 'reboot' wouldn't live up to my nostalgaic expectations.   For the most part, I think this game did very well, both in catering to old-timers like me, as well as provide content and gameplay for everyone. A few pros and cons:  Pros -- Respectful of the old game without replaying everything; the relocating of the HQ was nice touch, for example. I wonder if new players felt lost at all with all the references to the old game? It seemed like it was well-written to avoid such confusion, but I'm biased. (Am I the only one who got misty-eyed over Ace's death?) There's some fun humor throughout, such as the E.T. cartridges north of HQ and the descriptions of the overgrown vegetables. The mix of puzzling and fighting for missions was good, and the sharing of equipment between characters seemed to be about as good as any game could ever hope for. I liked the combat controls -- a good mix of real-time and turn-based mechanics. Interesting locations, great graphics, satisfying combat, fun characterization.  Cons -- The controls for moving seemed really awkward. For example, trying to see objects in tight rooms (like Ryan's pen in the East Field) was a pain, and the 'fog of war' seemed stingy. It was sometimes hard to see where you could and could not go. This complaint plus the suddenness of saving Ralphy in the Rail Nomad camp made that quest aggravating -- couldn't find Ralphy right away, and then he drowned as I was trying to figure out how to save him. Not really fair for just entering the camp. The swearing was a little off-putting as well, not only in how it seemed 'canned' and unnatural, but also in how it seemed to not quite fit in with the tone of the game. So, in short -- awkward viewing controls, high difficulty (even on 'easy'), counter-intuitive puzzling, and clunky potty mouth.  With a choice only between recommending or not recommending this game, I give it a mild thumbs up. On a scale of 1 to 10, I would have chosen '6' .....

Short version: Your enjoyment of this will very much depend on whether you enjoyed Fallout (1/2). If you haven't played them yet, play them instead.  I loved Fallout, so this ticked all of my nostalgia boxes. And really nostalgia is what this game is about. It's a top down post-apocalyptic cRPG with all the party building, xp grinding, side quest hunting goodness you could want. The different areas are mostly interesting. The side quests have multiple ways to resolve or screw up and don't always have a happy ending and often the game provides you with a choice of two (or three) equally bad outcomes. It's also rammed full of geek references  All in all it's hugely enjoyable.  But. It's not perfect. It's almost too caught up in nostalgia and could have done with some modern thinking applied to some of the mechanics. It's not particularly intuitive to start with and the lack of a decent in game tutorial will mean a lot of trial and error at the beginning. A few mechanics are clunky; for example, when you find a trap on a box you still have to explicitly use your demolitions skill to remove it as clicking the box with your demolitions expert will cause him to happily ignore the danger and open it anyway.   The camera thing, while pretty is a little pointless. I never found a situation where I wanted the view anything other than as high as possible and missing things due to not having the screen rotated the right way grates a little.  The first major location you hit will be one of two. Ag Center or Highpool. I hit Ag Center and it was long and tedious. It's not a great introduction to the game and may well result in people dropping the game at this point. Which would be a shame as it immediately improves 10-fold on moving on.  The second half of the game is hugely unfinished. Side quests can be completely bypassed by doing something slightly different and people will talk to you as though you were asked to perform the task and failed it. Then you'll find the side quest later on than you were supposed to, complete it (all the while being told it was a shame you couldn't resolve it) and everything will flip to the 'completed' state. It's as though inXile provided many paths to find/avoid/complete quests but didn't account for it in the dialog.  Nothing is insurmountable though and, with the odd little issue you can get through pretty much all the content. If you can put up with this, it's a blast.  It is, however, expensive. It's priced on a par with big AAA games. And while you can't say they're released bug free, they are generally a lot more polished than this is. I got it through Kickstarter and that was a perfectly acceptable price to pay for it. £30 though is too much.

Wasteland 2 is defintely a mixed bag. The game has all of classic features of the big post-apocalyptic ARPGs.   The Bad: The combat is good on the whole, but the way battles begin could be a lot better. The battles have an ambush feature, but outside of battle you can't set up an ambush for enemies you see ahead of you. You have two options, have one of your characters shoot at them first, or have all of your characters (which are typically bunch up in a formation I like to call 'Please throw a grenade at us') fire simultaneously. The second option usually results in one of your teammates getting a shotgun, or automatic volley, to the back. You can painstakingly set up each of teammates in position ahead of time, but that will usually trigger the battle. As with most games, enemy AI is not great and seldom do they use any sort of tactic other than running headfirst towards the nearest person and attacking. Like the original Fallout series some characters are voiced and some aren't. Nowadays this seems lazy. If TES IV Oblivion can get away with voicing thousands of NPCs with a handful of voice actors, so can this indy studio.  The plethora of jokes and Easter Eggs were a nice addition, but many of them have been used in both Wasteland and all of the Fallout games. They are getting old. Lastly, the sidequests were really tedious for the most part. Usually it involves getting a quest that leads to a secondary location in BFE, then needing to come back to the original location only to return to the second (or third location) again. Usually without anything interesting happening. I almost joined Matthias and his evil robot army just to wipe out all the Wastelanders that were too lazy to go on their own gopher runs.  The Good: Combat was solid and once you get your squad tuned up and outfitted, you can really wreak havoc on all manner of enemies.  Wasteland 2 gives a lot of playtime for the price. I bought it at full price and got sixty-three hours out of my first and only playthrough. That's a decent deal. There are some balancing issues with the skills and weapons, but I don't play these games for the battles as much as I do the story. I like that it doesn't do the Fallout 2 max at 99% weapon accuracy that somehow always seemed to miss far more often than 1%. Making your 1st character the 'speaker' for the party and maxing them out with all the speaking skills really opens up the game to you. It's sometimes hard to remember to flip to another party member who has a certain speaking skill, so keeping it all in the 1st player makes it a little easier to not accidentally skip past opportunities.  The point being, this game is very malleable and totally adaptable to however you want to play it. Easy mode is perfectly balanced for people like me who play for the story - battles are still fun and you get close to dying, but it's not too often my whole party goes down. I haven't tried it, but I'm sure the hard modes make the strategy and skill in the battles a lot more intense and challenging in a good way.  This is one of those games you don't want to beat because you don't want the journey to be over. Loving this renaissance in realizing that Iso games are the ♥♥♥♥ for RPG players.  My one MAJOR gripe with the game is that nothing is marked on your area map. The maps are pretty confusing to navigate sometimes - especially in big areas with lots of individual houses. The pathfinding AI is leaps ahead of old Iso games, but it still has its glitches here and there. It would be great if at least the shops were labelled, but I see absolutely no logic in not labelling places you've been to.  Would be amazing for Wasteland 3 to be the prequel to the destruction - you know it's going to happen, of course, but maybe there are ways you can affect the future somehow. Would just be a neat twist on the apocalyptical genre.

I'm not normally the type to pre-order games, but I bought this one at $59.99 while it was in Early Access, which is basically preorder. Here's the short version of my review:  I do not regret that decision.  I have bought a whopping two pre-order games in the past 5 years. The other was XCOM: The Bureau, because I was comming off a high from XCOM: Enemy Unknown and forgot that a shooter-XCOM was a ♥♥♥♥ing stupid idea. For Wasteland 2 it was due to a combination of love for Fallout 1&2 and outside recommendations. Wasteland 2 did not disappoint. Mostly.  If you liked Fallout 1 or 2, or never played them, give Wasteland 2 a shot. The story tone overall is dark, but it makes sure to lighten things up as you achieve goals, and there is a lot of hidden comedy to be found, adding a little bit of sillyness to the stark seriousness of the wastes. That might sound incongruous, but Brian Fargo's directing and his team's writing hold it together in a way that is sensical and digestible without becoming mundane. Events have weight and depth, and that weight gradually lifts as you succeed in goals, if only momentarily as the story progresses.  My only complaints are in the combat system. It isn't bad by any means; throw a dart at a game listing and you'll hit something worse. It just seems to be lacking a bit compared to Fallout 2. Overall the leveling and combat system are a fair bit simplified from the Fallout games, which I dislike a bit; while there is something to be said for simplicity, Fallout was still on the friendly side of the line of where too much complexity becomes a chore rather than fun, if only just. I guess my main complaint is that it led to an odd situation where I completely avoided wearing armor throughout the entire game as if it where plague-ridden, whereas in the venerable Fallout if you weren't wearing Powered Armor by act 5 you'll just spontaneously explode. So maybe it's a petty complaint, but a complaint nonetheless. Maybe I should just be glad that was one in-game expense I could completely ignore.  Other than that, it is a little difficult to believe that a character could be a master sniper and yet unable to hit the broadside of a barn if you hand them a shotgun, but what the hell, it's more combat focused than Fallout 1 or 2, so it is reasonable to expect the mechanical focus to shift towards combat, even if it does lead to some silly levels of specialization.   In summary, there's a few petty gripes for the long-term Fallout fans, but much like Bethesda's work, this is overall a positive development in that vein. If you want a good post-apocalyptic story or a squad-based combat game, then look no further. It's not perfect, but it is quite good.

Wasteland 2 is basically Fallout / Fallout 2, but you control a team instead of one person (companions still exist, called recruits here). It was made by Brian Fargo, the guy who listed his name as the creator for those games, along with a few other relevant names to make by my definition a great team of developers for this kind of project such as Liz Danforth and Chris Avellone, among others. The combat plays like a cross between Fallout / Fallout 2 and X-Com: Enemy Unknown, and the non-combat feels just like Fallout / Fallout 2, as well. W2's story context is in the game itself scattered throughout books and dialogue, so there is no requirement to play the original Wasteland to appreciate this game. The soundtrack is great with the exception of the GOD AWFUL ending theme song, the art direction is as expected for a post-apocalyptic game, and the game is quite long for modern single-player game standards. That last point is generally a good thing in my opinion, but I think that W2 exceeds that sweet spot of game length to promote replayability to the point where many players would not be making an effort to play through a second time any time soon after finishing W2.  Some faults: -This game is full of bugs and inconsistencies, to the point where one would think that this game is still in beta due to how it is such a central part of the gameplay experience. These bugs and inconsistencies will never get fixed, so be aware that you are playing a game which feels as though it did not really undergo any quality control between the ending of the beta and when the live, 'complete' game launched. -In inconsistencies, there are many white-named items which indicate importance, but have no purpose whatsoever and are just mislabelled junk items. -Another important thing to consider with said inconsistencies is that the description for all energy weapons is backwards. Using the Meson Cannon as an example, it says that it has an armour threshold of 3, and that its threshold damage multipliers are 0.4x damage above 3 armour on the target, 0.9x at 3 armour, and 2.2x below 3 armour. This indicates that energy weapons do more damage to lower-armour targets. All energy weapons are listed in this format, and all of them are listed WRONG in this way; the skill description itself tells you correctly that energy weapons do less damage to unarmoured targets, but the weapons say the opposite. You end up doing 2.2x damage with the Meson Cannon to targets with above 3 armour and 0.4x damage to targets below 3 armour, and so on for every energy weapon. -Pistols, sub-machine guns, and shotguns are pretty worthless because of their range. I believe that the highest range I saw was 21 metres with mods to extend the range as far as possible, whereas I had assault rifles often over 40 metres, and sniper rifles over 50 metres. This makes a HUGE difference in combat efficacy. Melee as a main combat discipline is also worthless for the same reason, but it works well enough if the enemies get close enough to you where you do not have to go to them to use melee. -Portraits are reused HEAVILY, to the point where supposedly meaningful NPCs end up sharing the same portraits with nobodies from the wastes. It seems really lazy imo to only make a small handful of portraits and recycle them; not using any at all would have been a better choice than reusing the same several. -The proper endings, like with the endings for the Fallout games, is the phoned-in slideshow which cheapened the efforts put forth to complete the game.  All in all, this is a great game in spite of its problems, and I highly recommend it if you enjoyed the original Fallout games. The devs like to tout that someone once called it 'game of the year,' but let us be honest here: unless that year is 1996 or prior, it most likely will not be the best game of any given year that you play it.

Wasteland 2 is both fun and challenging while having it's nice funny moments while you're paving your road with blood and corpses. You start with 4 cool blokes who you can modify yourself or just go with... premade characters if you're into that. You can even do anything you please in their customization up to their biography if you are so inclined and since it is RNG based you can have your own little stories about your guys like my sniper 'Dead End' ambush sniping everyone into their own little dead end... in a bloody explosion that involves their head.  With the pros there's a solid combat system, lovely music score, solid story and properly fleshed out characters out there. Some love you on sight while others hate you, and of course there are some that just don't really care about you until you do something.   Most of all your decisions make an impact on the world while some not being obvious. Do you help this faction or that other one? Can one of your decisions is to do nothing and hope it solves itself? Yeah, you can choose to do nothing. And then you get to deal with all the consequences of those decisions.   Oh, and if you feel like it you can kill everyone you meet. Is this a good idea? Probably not... but this kind of thing is what I'm going to judge other RPGs on. Such as you don't like how someone looked at you? You can kill them. You don't like goats? You can shoot them. Such as random encounters using the same map repeatedly. Slow on response, especially on the world map.  So yeah, if you like cRPGs that use Action Points and where character stats matter you'll like this game.

I didn't play the old Fallouts to compare with this game, and I don't want to compare. In fact, I like to see every single game by itself, and, for my taste, I think Wasteland 2 really worth my money.  I not finished the game yet but I already played it a lot. I like the combat mechanics - in which you have to buy and do a good use of ammunition -, and choose specialities for each weapon, having a lot of space to move with balanced AP. Basic turn-based combat, right? But this seems more free and even realistic to me. And it's nice to create a character and give him all habilities and particularities you want, even writing a bio! So I can have somebody that is good on weapons, another on healing, another on locks and alarms, etc.  One of the most interesting things in this game is the choices we have to make, and the reactions of all the world about it. Some games promise to give us freedom to do anything, but the ends are always the same. In Wasteland 2 you really see things changing, now or later. Some choices are easy, and others are really drastic. So you really need to think about everything.  Oh! And I really like the humor on this game. I laugh about the junks I loot, I like to read the lore, and the achievements are also funny. Everything is always getting me by surprise.  Graphics are good, too. A little boring, but it works well in high quality in my old pc. And until now I didn't have problems with graphics or bugs, just some delay on characters movements. But keep in mind that they will brings a big change soon, so graphics will be better, we'll have mod support, etc.  I highly recommend it! Give Wasteland 2 a chance if you like turn-based, choices, humor and post-apocalyptic world! It will give you a good time, some laughs and a lot of indecisions. :)
